statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

article.description: Dee Brown scored 18 points and Roger Powell added 16 points and 10 rebounds to lead No. 12 Illinois to a 93-61 Wednesday night over Mercer.
article.headline: Illini's Powell grabs double-double
article.linkText: No. 12 Illinois has no mercy on lowly Mercer
article.story: CHAMPAIGN, Ill. (AP) -- Roger Powell is a believer in Bruce Weber's philosophy that good defense makes the offense better. "Coach is getting on me about rebounding," the Illinois forward said Wednesday night after grabbing 10 in the Illini's 93-61 win over Mercer. "Our big guys went to the boards hard, which opens up rebounding opportunities." The 12th-ranked Illini manhandled Mercer (1-3) on the boards, winning the battle by 17. Six of Powell's 10 rebounds were off the offensive glass. "Coach always says if you can focus on defense the offense becomes better," he said. "We played hard defense and it seemed that made the offense better and made it easier for us to score." Powell added 16 points to the 10 rebounds for his first career double-double. Dee Brown led the Illini (2-0) in scoring with 18 points. Deron Williams scored 14 points, a new career high, and Nick Smith had 13 for the Illini, who have scored more than 90 points in each of their two games this season. "They really put it on us tonight. They were really difficult to keep off both boards," said Mercer coach Mark Slonaker. "Their defensive pressure in the first half was really outstanding." Illinois' speed and motion offense was too much for Mercer from the start. The Illini were able to move the ball to their front line for short shots, which let Brown roam free on the perimeter. He hit three of his four 3-pointers in the first half. The Illini used a 24-7 run to build a 30-10 lead with 8:42 left in the first half. Mercer made only three of eight shots and committed six turnovers over that 9-minute span as the Illini pushed a 6-3 lead to 20 points. "When they get in a transition game, they're as good as anybody in the country," Slonaker said. Mercer lost its third straight game despite 15 points from Jacob Skogen.Scott Emerson scored 14 points for the Bears, who shot only 40 percent from the floor and committed 21 turnovers. "Right when they started doing some good things we just pushed it right down their throats," Weber said. "We got some easy layups and some nice run-outs. There's nothing more demoralizing for a team than to score a bucket and then to have a layup before you can even turn around." Illinois led by as many as 36 points and never trailed by fewer than 30 after the break in running its Assembly Hall winning streak to 19 games. Illinois plays its next four games away from the Assembly Hall, beginning with Temple on Saturday. They play North Carolina in Greensboro, N.C., Arkansas in Chicago and Providence in New York before playing their next game in Champaign. "We're going to have to be much tougher than we were tonight," Weber said.
